One of the things that concerns a lot of families is that the federal system bases eligibility on their 2008 income and their parents' 2008 income.
Students want to know what to do when mom or dad lost a job, and it's important that families know that they can apply and have their aid revised based on their 2009 circumstance.

And even though there is aid available, and big part of your job is to persuade people that that's the case, do you sometimes come across people who want to go to college and you say look, there's just no way.

I don't see that.
The question happens when a student is fully funded and the family circumstances are so extreme that they can't afford the student to go to college at no cost.
They need the student to stay home and earn money to help keep the family afloat.
That's the one very discouraging circumstance that we see as the result of this economy.

I think of a grandmother who had taken on the care of her grandchildren, who was just sure that there was no hope and no way that her obviously bright high school junior was going to have any chance of going to college.

And when she saw the outcome, that there really was a federal Pell Grant, that he would be eligible for work study, which is included in the stimulus bill, you could watch the visible relief on her face, followed by joy and excitement that her grandchild might have a different future than she and even her children had experience.
We know that the fastest way to eliminate poverty in America is to have just one member of the family go to college.

It made it absolutely worth any time, any effort, anything that I could have seen to see that hope on her face.
